prompts.prompt: Why did the Tokugawa Bakufu decide to close Japan to most foreigners? Explain the specific threats they were trying to prevent.
rubric: European missionaries (especially Portuguese) were converting Japanese people to Christianity
By 1587, approximately 150,000 Japanese had converted in the Nagasaki area
The Bakufu feared Christianity would undermine the existing social and political order
European nations had colonized other parts of Asia — Japan saw this as a warning
The Bakufu wanted to protect Japan's sovereignty and maintain control

prompts.prompt: Describe the main rules of the Closed Country Edict of 1635. What did this edict require and forbid?
rubric: No Japanese person could go abroad (penalty of death)
No Japanese living abroad could return to Japan
Christianity must be stamped out/destroyed
Anyone reporting a Christian priest would be rewarded
Foreign ships must be inspected for priests
No offspring of Southern Barbarians (Europeans) could remain in Japan

prompts.prompt: Explain why merchants were ranked near the bottom of the social hierarchy in Edo Japan, even though many of them were wealthy. What does this tell us about Edo Japanese values?
rubric: The social hierarchy was based on Confucian values, not wealth
Merchants were seen as producing nothing — they only bought and sold goods others made
Farmers and artisans were ranked higher because they produced food and useful goods
Despite low social rank, merchants often had more money than samurai
This shows Edo Japan valued contribution to society and loyalty over individual wealth

prompts.prompt: How did the Tokugawa Bakufu maintain control over the powerful daimyo (feudal lords)? Describe at least four specific laws or strategies they used.
rubric: No contact was allowed between daimyo (to prevent alliances)
Only one castle allowed per domain (limiting military strength)
Daimyo had to spend every second year living in Edo (sankin-kotai) — kept them under watch and drained their wealth
Daimyo had to fund public building projects (reducing their resources)
All marriages of daimyo needed Bakufu permission
All must register at Buddhist temples (surveillance)
Travel and shipbuilding were restricted

prompts.prompt: Explain the two levels of government that existed in Edo Japan. How did they work together, and who was in charge at each level?
rubric: The Han was the local level of government, run by the daimyo in each domain
The Bakufu was the centralized government, run by the Shogun from Edo
The Bakufu had authority over all the han and could enforce laws on daimyo
The Emperor existed as a figurehead/spiritual leader but had no real political power
The Shogun held the real political and military power over all of Japan

prompts.prompt: Why did popular culture (Kabuki theatre, woodblock prints, Bunraku) flourish during the Edo period? What conditions made this possible?
rubric: The long period of peace meant people had more leisure time
Cities grew and the merchant class became wealthy and influential
More people desired luxury items and entertainment
Daimyo became patrons of the arts, funding cultural activities
Samurai turned their creative energies to intellectual pursuits like prose and poetry
Woodblock printing made art affordable and widely available

prompts.prompt: The Dutch were allowed to set up a trading post on Deshima island during Japan's period of isolation. Why were they given this special treatment? What made Deshima a clever solution for the Bakufu?
rubric: The Dutch had not brought missionaries, proving they were only interested in trade
Unlike the Portuguese and Spanish, the Dutch did not try to spread Christianity
Deshima was an artificial island, so it was technically not Japanese soil
This meant the Bakufu could claim foreigners were not really on Japanese land
The arrangement let Japan benefit from trade while maintaining the closed country policy

prompts.prompt: Describe how the three great leaders — Oda Nobunaga, Toyotomi Hideyoshi, and Tokugawa Ieyasu — each contributed to the unification of Japan.
rubric: Oda Nobunaga began the process by conquering territories and building castles and administrative systems
Toyotomi Hideyoshi continued unification by introducing the koku tax system based on rice production
Hideyoshi created a rigid class structure that froze social mobility
Hideyoshi also built a standing army
Tokugawa Ieyasu finalized unification after winning the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600
Ieyasu established the Tokugawa Shogunate in 1603 with Edo as the capital

prompts.prompt: Even though Japan had a policy of isolation, foreign influence still reached the country. Explain how outside ideas and knowledge entered Japan during the Closed Country period.
rubric: The Dutch traded from Deshima island and shared knowledge, especially in medicine and surgery
Chinese and Korean traders were permitted limited access to Japan
Some Japanese officials could visit foreign places like the Ryuku Islands and Korea
Chinese influence actually increased because their goods and ideas were among the few allowed in
Dutch surgeons taught Japanese scholars new medical techniques, changing their understanding of the body
Exposure to foreign ideas changed Japanese scholars' worldview, affecting future generations

prompts.prompt: Describe the three metropolises of Edo Japan — Edo, Kyoto, and Osaka. What was each city known for, and why was it important?
rubric: Edo was the seat of the Shogun's military government, a port city known as the 'city of water'
Kyoto was the former imperial capital where the Emperor resided, known for luxury items and cultural refinement
Osaka developed around a protected harbour and became the centre of the Japanese economy
Osaka was called the 'kitchen of Japan' for its wonderful markets
Osaka was famous for its castle, 150 bridges, and for setting the standard rice price
